Deficiency Narrative:
During a review conducted on August 19, 2025, it was determined that: 
(1)	your operations administrator failed to ensure compliance with the current HM Plan; and 
(2)	more than 12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.
As you know, the heightened monitoring plan for your operation included a specific planned end date at the original 12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring.  As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plan, your operation was unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring by the original planned end date necessitating previous extension.  Furthermore, due to your recent citations issued on June 6, 2025, your operations planned end date must now be revised again, and the period of heightened monitoring must be extended again. 
Further details of the administrators failure to ensure compliance include the following: 
Your operation received a high weighted citation in a pattern/trend category on June 6, 2025.  Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.685(a)(4): Caregiver responsibility - During DFPS investigation staff reported having earphones on and admitted to having their eyes closed while working the overnight shift. The purpose of this standard is to protect the health, safety, and well-being of children by ensuring adequate supervision. Supervision is a basic element to the prevention of harm. The operation met compliance on 7/10/2025. 
-	Operation failed to satisfy the conditions of the plan.
-	Operation failed to demonstrate 6 months of successive compliance with the standard and contract requirements that led to heightened monitoring.
-	Operation was unable to meet compliance with high weighted licensing citation.
Finding: 748.535(2)  The licensed administrator must ensure the operation complies with current heightened monitoring plan.
Correction Narrative: An HM extension was approved effective 8/19/2025.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 2/18/2026.

Deficiency Narrative: Suicide screening that was provided was denied to have been completed by staff and child in care.
Correction Narrative:
8/27/2025 Follow-up by inspection (4072748), discussed with medical staff the process of documenting required information related to screenings in the operation online system.   

7/31/2025 email received with CAP, trainings sign-in sheet and email about one-on-one conversation with staff involved.

Deficiency Narrative: Suicide screening was not completed immediately after child in care was found with a t-shirt around their neck.
Correction Narrative:
8/27/2025 Follow-up by inspection (4072748), medical staff was interviewed regarding the screening process and documenting required information in the operation online system.   

7/31/2025 email received with CAP, trainings sign-in sheet and email about one-on-one conversation with staff involved.  
CAP-Immediate Action:
 One-on-one supervision will be conducted with the nurse and therapist involved by 07.31.2025 to review scenarios that would prompt a suicide screen, accurate reporting expectations, coordinating documentation responsibilities, and what to expect during regulatory interviews.
 Refresher training will be completed with the nurse and therapist involved by 07.31.2025 in suicide screening procedures, documentation protocols, and post-incident debrief expectations.
 While this is will not be the norm quality assurance will provide one-on-one feedback by 07.31.2025 on how to properly document information on that has been gathered via a phone call whether  in real time or during a follow-up. 

Ongoing Monitoring and Process Improvement:
 This plan ensures that identified situations are addressed promptly and accurately through intensified oversight and clearly defined performance expectations.
 We will continue to monitor the proper completion of suicide risk screenings in all situations where a child exhibits warning signs that warrant such assessments. Any gaps in practice will be addressed immediately through targeted coaching and support to reinforce consistent adherence to suicide screening protocols.

Deficiency Narrative: The medication count was documented incorrectly on the med log for a child s  prescribed medication.
Correction Narrative:
The operation provided the following corrective action via email on 05.27.25:

1. Targeted Training for Medical Team
a. The identified medical staff will receive refresher training on the proper procedure for
documenting medication counts, including how to record pills administered, remaining
inventory, and discarded medication.
b. The training will emphasize the importance of accuracy in Medication Administration Records
(MAR) and will include examples of common documentation errors and how to avoid them.
c. Completion Deadline: June 3, 2025.
2. Oversight and Quality Assurance Review
a. A MAR audit will be integrated into the daily medical communication log to ensure consistency
and promote daily accountability.
b. Medication Administration Records will be audited "two deep": the first audit will be completed
by the Residential Medical Supervisor, followed by a second review conducted by a member of
administration
3. Upcoming EMAR Implementation
a. New Life is in the process of rolling out an Electronic Medication Administration Record (EMAR)
system this summer. This system includes built-in safeguards to prevent medication
documentation discrepancies, such as real-time inventory tracking, auto-calculation of remaining
doses, and immediate alerts for missing entries.
b. We believe this transition will significantly enhance medication accuracy and accountability
across all shifts.
Identified staff training certificate and training sign-in sheet received.

Deficiency Narrative: During DFPS investigation staff reported having earphones on and admitted to having their eyes closed while working the overnight shift.
Correction Narrative:
07/17/2025- received training sign-in sheet list overnight staff. 

07/16/2025- FOLLOW-UP inspection conducted, interviewed the Director of Operations on steps taken. MSR- left PENDING, until training documents received. Training schedule for the evening of 7/16/2025. 

07/15/2025- email received from operation stating training will be completed on 7/16/225 instead of 7/15/2025 as indicated in CAP. One day extension granted. 
 

07/10/2025 CAP received from operation: 
Policy Reinforcement: All overnight direct care staff will receive refresher training on supervision standards, with emphasis on alert supervision while youth are sleeping, and inattentiveness, no later than 07/15/2025.

Enhanced Monitoring: For the next 60 days, the Residential Dorm Supervisor working the overnight shift will increase the dorm walk-throughs to two per hour between the hours of 12:00 am and 5:00 am to verify staff is alert and offer additional short breaks if staff need to step outside to refresh.
Performance Accountability: Supervisors will document monthly follow-up conversations to make sure all overnight staff are aligned with supervision best practices and any future infractions will be addressed through progressive disciplinary action up to and including separation.

Ongoing Oversight:
The overnight residential dorm supervisor will be granted camera access to monitor all dorm staff for alertness through the overnight hours. The Program Manager will be responsible for verifying the completion of the refresher training as well as follow-up supervisions.

AR will not be requested.

Deficiency Narrative: A child in care, with identified high risk behaviors, was not provided 15-minute wellness checks and was left alone in the residence by a staff member.
Correction Narrative:
6/13/2025 received email with CAP- We are submitting the following corrective action plan for this investigation and will not be requesting an
administrative review.

This failure is supervision created a serious safety concern and was addressed immediately. Upon internal review, it was determined that this was an isolated incident caused by a single staff member's failure to follow established supervision protocols. This was not reflective of broader practice and was promptly addressed as a targeted performance issue. Existing procedures and training were found to be clear and comprehensive; therefore, no
adjustments are needed to overall supervision policies or trainings are required at this time.
1. Immediate Action:
a. In response, the staff member was required to complete one-on-one coaching with the Program
Trainer as part of the broader corrective actions outlined in their internal Performance Improvement
Plan.
b. This session focused on supervision best practices, including executing line-of-sight visual checks during 15-minute intervals, the expectations outlined in the 24-Hour Awake Supervision policy, and the importance of thorough room checks, particularly during transitions.
2. Performance Oversight:
a. The identified staff member was placed on the highest level of an internal Performance Improvement Plan, effective immediately.
i. For the first 30 days, the Residential Dorm Supervisor will conduct increased documented
supervision, including unannounced spot checks and direct observation during transitions.

Additionally, the staffs monthly supervisions with the Program Manager will increase to a
bi-monthly schedule for a period of three months to review documentation and performance feedback.
iii. While the Performance Improvement Plan is an internal accountability tool, we want to note
that this incident will be treated with zero tolerance for the duration of the plan, which in
this case will span 12 months.
3. Ongoing Monitoring and Process Improvement:
a. This plan ensures that the identified staff member is held directly accountable through intensified oversight and clear performance expectations.
b. We will continue to monitor supervision practices across all shifts. Any gaps will be addressed promptly through targeted coaching and support to reinforce consistent adherence to supervision expectations.

Deficiency Narrative: Fire extinguisher are NOT being inspected monthly.
Correction Narrative: A follow inspection was completed, the operation provided documentation for the fire extingusher inspections.

Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.685(a)(3): Caregiver responsibility - Child in care was left unsupervised inside the dorm. Deficiency Narrative: On video, a staff member was seen shoving a child to prevent them from going into the room of a peer.
Correction Narrative:
Follow-up conducted; training documents received see MI#4044427

2/12/2025 email received.  
Corrective Action Plan:
To ensure compliance with regulatory standards and prevent future incidents, the following corrective actions will
be implemented:
1. Targeted Staff Retraining
-The TCI Certified Trainer will provide one-on-one retraining to the staff member identified in the
video.
 The 2-hour retraining will focus on TCI interventions for de-escalation and managing crisis situations as well as reviewing the footage through the lens of TCI.
-Completion Deadline: February 21, 2025
2. Child Rights Training for All Direct Care Staff
- All direct care staff will receive Childs Rights training emphasizing the right to be free from harsh, cruel, unusual, unnecessary, demeaning, or humiliating treatment or punishment
(748.1101(b)(4)(A)) and 748.2303 (Subchapter M) Discipline & Punishment.
- Completion Deadline: February 21, 2025
3. Compliance Monitoring
-The Program Trainer will ensure that all staff remain current on TCI Refresher courses and Child
Rights trainings.
-The Program Manager and/or Manager on Duty will continue to review and debrief all critical
incidents with direct care staff to identify and implement additional training as necessary.

Deficiency Narrative: Child in care was left unsupervised inside the dorm.
Correction Narrative:
12/31/2024-follow up conducted at the operation discussed with Director and management systems put in place to ensure youth are accounted for. Postings were also observed during inspection.  
12/22/2024 email received from operation
Corrective Action:
1. Immediate Action:
 A visual "Headcount" posting will be prominently displayed by or on the doors as a constant
reminder for staff to complete multiple headcounts, particularly when transitioning to and from
the dorms.
 The Residential Dorm Supervisor (RDS) will conduct an additional walk-through of all dorms
immediately after the last dorm transitions to school each day. This ensures that all children are
accounted for.
 If the RDS is unavailable due to unforeseen circumstances, the RDS will immediately contact the
administration building to arrange for an alternative staff member to complete the room checks.
2. Daily Accountability:
 This procedure has been added to the morning RDSs daily checklist. The checklist will be
reviewed daily by either the Manager on Duty (MOD) or the Program Manager (PM) to ensure
compliance.
3. Monitoring and Follow-up:
 The MOD or PM will review the completion of the RDSs morning checklist to ensure consistent
adherence to the corrective action. Regular audits will be conducted as needed to assess the
effectiveness of this plan and ensure ongoing compliance.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation did not report a diagnosed communicable disease to licensing.
Correction Narrative:
11/20/2024- follow up conducted with operation. Director has met with head nurse and discussed the systems put in place. 
During inspection 4030806 posting mention in #2 in CAP was observed and information was also confirmed by speaking with the nurse.  

11/13/24- An email was sent by the operation's Director of Operations with the following compliance response: " Corrective Action: 1. The Program Trainer will review the RTC Reportable incident Guide with a focus on medical incidents as well as the Texas DSHS Administrative Code Chapter 97.3(a)(1-5) What Condition to Report and What isolates to Report or Submit.
2. The most current list of the Texas Notifiable Conditions form the TXDSHS website will be posted in the medical building for easy reference.
3. Any lab results will be reviewed timely by medical staff and supervisor before uploading into EVOLV.
4. Weekly medical updates will be an added topic to staffing meetings, so the reportable conditions can have ongoing monitoring with Directors and Managers.

Deficiency Narrative: A child in care did not receive medical treatment for a fracture until two days after their injury.
Correction Narrative:
7/11/2024- all medical staff will review and sign a copy of 748.1531 acknowledging understanding the importance and receive additional training on the operations after-hours & weekend incident on-call guide.  
The training will cover specific procedures to follow during non-office hours for different incidents focusing on illness, injury and other medical incidents. The training will also address timelines and who to notify. Staff will be provided a copy of the on-call guide and reference chart after completions of the training, completed no later than 7/16/2024.
The guide and chart will be posted in the nurse's office. Both topics will be reviewed and discussed in 1:1 Supervisions over the next few months.

On 1/2/24, a follow up inspection was completed. Supervision and ratio were observed compliant on a walkthrough. Staffing was discussed with management. A child and staff were interviewed with no concerns for supervision/ratio. 

On 12/27/23, the administrator responded that the Program Director, Program Manager, and Manager-On-Duty will review, with program staff, Minimum Standard 748.1009(2) and Policy # RTC 501 Child-Caregiver Ratios that requires a sufficient number of caregivers to provide supervision to children in care. The operation continues to implement a staffing plan to increase staff available. 

During the administrative review process, it was determined that standard 748.537(a) was a more applicable standard for the finding. Previous follow up was determined to meet compliance.

Deficiency Narrative: Two staff interviewed made statements that the staff to child ratio exceeded 1:5 during the incident. One staff said there were eight children. Another said there were at least six children. Interviews confirm two staff were present, however, one staff was in observations and not counted into ratio on the day of the incident. Management confirms the staff was not counted into ratio during their interview.
Correction Narrative: Two staff interviewed made statements that the staff to child ratio exceeded 1:5 during the incident. One staff said there were eight children. Another said there were at least six children. Interviews confirm two staff were present, however, one staff was in observations and not counted into ratio on the day of the incident. Management confirms the staff was not counted into ratio during their interview.

Deficiency Narrative: Medication was prepared four hours before time of administration.
Correction Narrative: On 1/20, the administrator provided a response that the staff that prepared the medication early will receive a refresher training that will cover all medication management protocols and procedures.

Deficiency Narrative: After reviewing video footage, EBI curriculum, and staff statements, Emergency Behavioral Intervention training was not utilized on the aggressive child as required by the extent of possible physical injury. The child's hair was pulled twice, and she was kicked four times prior to the caregiver pulling out phone to call for assistance. The decision was made not to restrain the aggressive child without assistance despite the behaviors needing further management.
Correction Narrative: Staff member involved will attend a refresher training on Active Listening and Crisis Co-regulation. The incident tape recording will be reviewed with the staff. A discussion on what can be done to improve will be held.

Deficiency Narrative: In video footage reviewed, the caregiver exhibits a lack of urgency and fails to protect the child from harm. Body positioning was not positioned to protect the child from injury. The aggressive child was not restrained, and the targeted child was not removed.
Correction Narrative: Staff member involved will attend a refresher training on Active Listening and Crisis Co-regulation. The incident tape recording will be reviewed with the staff. A discussion on what can be done to improve will be held.

Deficiency Narrative: Shower was dirty and coming apart from wall.
Correction Narrative: Bathrooms were observed clean and in good repair to include Olsen Left. There are additional improvements in progress for the bathroom such as new mirrors.

Deficiency Narrative: Staff member used profanity and yelled at children in care.
Correction Narrative: Management emailed to inform the staff member was suspended after the incident and terminated after the results of the investigation were released. The staff's training record and the operation's zero tolerance policy were provided.

Deficiency Narrative: During the walk through a wooden picnic table was seen blocking the side door.

During a review conducted on August 5, 2022, it was determined that: 

(1)	your operations administrator failed to ensure compliance with the current HM Plan(s); and 

(2)	more than 12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.

As you know, the heightened monitoring plans for your operation included a specific planned end date at the original 12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring.  As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plans, your operation was unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring by the original planned end date necessitating previous extension.  

Furthermore, due to your recent citations issued on July 20, 2022, your operations planned end date must now be revised again, and the period of heightened monitoring must be extended again. 

Further details of the failure of your operations administrator to ensure compliance include the following: 
The operation received a medium and medium-high weighted citation in a pattern/trend category on July 20, 2022. Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.2151(c)(6) and 748.2151(d) related to medication documentation. The operation met compliance on July 25, 2022. 
-	Operation failed to demonstrate 6 months of successive compliance with the standard and contract requirements that led to heightened monitoring; and
-	Operation was unable to meet compliance with Medium-High or High weighted licensing citations. 

Finding: 748.535(2)  The licensed administrator must ensure the operation complies with current heightened monitoring plans.
Correction Narrative:
Corrective Action: 
Administrator will place systems in place to ensure and support compliance to the current HM Plans including reassigning of personnel and duty responsibilities to specific tasks that are highlighted by HM as areas of need, 
adding the position of Quality Control Manager to support documentation oversight, creating a new An HM extension was approved effective 08/05/2022.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 02/06/2023.

Deficiency Narrative: 1 out of 3 child s medication record reviewed it was discovered that a psychotropic medication count was  documented incorrectly on the medication log.
Correction Narrative: Staff members demonstrating a deficiency in medication documentation are required to attend a three-hour medication documentation observation/training

Deficiency Narrative: During the review of three child medication records if was noticed that two staff who administered medication to a child in care had not written their name and/or signature in the section provided on the bottom of the medication log to identify their initials.
Correction Narrative: Staff members demonstrating a deficiency in medication documentation are required to attend a three-hour medication documentation observation/training.

Deficiency Narrative: Two of the three child records reviewed did not have the child s TB test results located in the child s records. However the operation was able to request one child's TB test results  and placed it in the child's file.
One of the three child records reviewed did not have an up to date TB test.
Correction Narrative: Executive Director, Clinical Director, and Program Director will review and provide refresher trainings on TB test requirement listed in Minimum Standards 748.1583(a).

Deficiency Narrative: During the review of employee records, it was discovered that two direct care staff  had not completed their required annual trainings.
Correction Narrative:
The direct care staff member will meet with the Program Manager and Program Trainer to review and discuss 
Minimum Standards and Upbrings Policy & Procedures that specifically addresses training requirements.

Deficiency Narrative: During the review of a child's medication record it was discovered that a psychotropic medication count was documented incorrectly on the medication log.
One prescription medication was not documented as administered within the two hour timeframe.
A youth in care was left alone in the unit unsupervised.
Correction Narrative: Administration sent a compliance plan on 01/06/2022 to the licensing representative. The plan was received by the inspector on 01/13/2022. The administrator provided a corrective action plan and New Life will review, with the staff member involved, Upbrings Policy & Procedures that specifically addresses responsibilities of our caregivers and supervision of a child (specifically our Caregiver policy # 1217).

Deficiency Narrative: A resident was on a safety plan and staff did not check on resident while showering.  Resident got ahold of her hygiene and ingested her bottle of shampoo.
Correction Narrative:
New Life staff members involved will review Upbrings Policy & Procedures that specifically addresses youth safety (Youth Safety Status & Precaution / Restriction Policy # 1282). 

Interview with Program Manager - staff reviewed and trained on residents on a safety plan.
Staff will stand in doorway with door open and will be within hearing range of the resident.
Staff will not let resident be by themselves alone in bathroom, while on safety plan.

Deficiency Narrative: There was only one caregiver for 9 children for 30 minutes during the morning shift. The other staff memeber that was supposed to be on the unit had called in, and a replacement for the staff was not sent to the unit.
Correction Narrative: 8/25/21- An email was received from the administrator. The Administrator stated in the email that the staff that were involved with their unit being out of ratio, will be required to attend a review training that will cover child/caregiver ratio and internal operational responses to callouts, including notifications, resource allocation, and order of operations that will help prevent a reoccurrence of situation that lead to the deficiency.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation staff discouraged children in care from writing grievances.
Correction Narrative: New Life staff member involved will review Upbrings Policy & Procedures that specifically addresses child rights (Childrens Rights Policy # 1227 and Client Grievances Policy #1207).

Deficiency Narrative:
Last health inspection was completed on 
4/30/2019. Therefore, operation did not complete the annual required health inspection.
Correction Narrative: New Life provided a letter from the Texas Department of State Health Services to the monitors on the day of their visit.  This letter, dated 5/11/21, stated that DSHS PHR 8 had suspended regulatory inspections until further notice due COVID-19.  This letter also stated that DSHS PHR 8 would be in contact with us when inspections resume to complete the mandatory Health Inspection.  New Life has continued to reach out to DSHS in attempts to get a health inspection completed.

Deficiency Narrative: The med log in the Olsen unit did not have staff's initials who administered meds for the PM shift on 7/6/21.
Correction Narrative: An email was sent by Executive Director, Jonathon Stanford in response to the citation. They are taking corrective action by requiring those who administer medication to take the DFPS online psychotropic medication training and/or attend a medication administration training. In addition, during the inspection, the Program Director, Yolanda Cantu stated they would discuss the error with the assigned staff and make corrections.

Deficiency Narrative: Resident was standing on a table and staff moved the table causing resident to fall onto the ground, resulting in a fractured shoulder.
Correction Narrative: Email received from Michael Holder, Director.  At the townhall meeting the program trainer scheduled two trainings for 9/18/21.  This time it is children's rights and a review of the Repair process based on the outcome of this investigation.

Correction Narrative: Email received from Michael Holder, Director.  At the townhall meeting the program trainer scheduled two trainings for 9/18/21.  This time it is children's rights and a review of the Repair process based on the outcome of this investigation.

Awake Supervision of Youth policy and procedure, with a special emphasis on the During Transitions section.  An assessment over this specific section was also completed.

Deficiency Narrative: Staff threw a water bottle and struck resident in the face.

The staff initiating the restraint attended a Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (EBI) refresher training on June 11th.  Staff also reviewed the videos, including this specific incident, that have been investigated and/or citations given.   This review included discussion of antecedents and actual behaviors (including staffs) that led to restraint and/or incident.

The staff initiating the restraint attended a Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (EBI) refresher training on June 11th. Deficiency Narrative: Investigation documentation reveals operation staff had a note from a child in care expressing intention to commit suicide and shortly after the child in care was seen with a jacket around their neck and would not remove the jacket until staff threatened to cut the jacket off with scissors. The operation admits they did not count this as a suicide attempt and didn't report it.
Correction Narrative:
New Life will review Minimum Standard 748.305  What constitutes a suicide attempt by a child?
A suicide attempt is a childs attempt to take his own life using means or methods for causing his death, including any act a child commits intending to cause his death, but excluding suicidal gestures where it is clear that the act was unlikely to cause death. Suicidal thoughts are not reportable as a suicide attempt

Deficiency Narrative: A staff member shoved a resident in between restraints.
Correction Narrative: New Life will review our Therapeutic Crisis Intervention curriculum.  Specifically, we will review the Managing the Crisis module.

Deficiency Narrative: Staff supervise all children in care when calls are made, resulting in calls not remaining private.
Correction Narrative: An email was received from the administrator stating New Life will review Minimum Standard 748.1101(b)(7) with all clinical staff and those program staff who are able to provide phone calls for the youth.  It will be emphasized that any phone calls made to the DFPS Texas Abuse/Neglect Hotline or the Ombudsman by youth are to be private, unless youth is currently on any Safety Precautions.

Deficiency Narrative: True and accurrate information was not reported in a complete timely manner.

This review will be completed by Jonathon Stanford (Associate Executive Director), Diane Quiroga (Clinical Director), or Michael Holder (Program Director).

Deficiency Narrative: Medication records, a professional medical collateral, medical care staff, direct care staff and child in care interviews together confirm a child in care missed one dose on one evening of a medication causing the child in care to feel upset and tired.
Correction Narrative: Medications will remain in the Medication Carts where they are typically stored until the youth leaves for the pass.  When staff go to pick up the youth from their cottage/dorm, they will then pick up their medications as well, if needed.

Deficiency Narrative: Child in care was restrained multiple times during on week.
Correction Narrative: New Life will review Division 11  Triggered Reviews of the minimum standards for GROs with administrative personnel.

Deficiency Narrative: Three residents were "cheeking" their medication and storing them in their room.
Correction Narrative: New Life will review our 24-hr. Awake Supervision of Youth P&P the focuses on Medication Administration (see next page).  Supervisors will also observe, as much as possible, the administration of medications.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection of fire extinguisher it was found that staff did not have access to the lock box where the fire extinguishers were located.
Correction Narrative:
1/18/2021- an email was received from the administrator, who provided the compliance response. The following is the response for the citation issued:
New Life provided keys to the staff that didnt have one for the fire extinguisher lock box.  We will place a spare key in the middle office of each dorm that has lock boxes.  Also, we conduct a key audit with staff to ensure all caregivers have a key to the lockbox.

Deficiency Narrative: Operation staff admitted that COVID 19 positive test results for a staff member were not reported within 24 hours.
Correction Narrative: New Life will designate a person responsible, along with a backup, to report all COVID 19 positive tests.

Deficiency Narrative: Staff admitted to yelling and making inappropriate statements to child in care at the operation.

Deficiency Narrative: Three child service plans did not identify a plan to minimize the risk to the child or other due to the child's high risk behaviors.
Correction Narrative:
12/14/2020- The administrator sent an email to show compliance to the citation issued at the November 30, 2020 heightened monitoring visit. The following is the administrator's response:

On December 1, 2020, New Life provided updated training to therapists and case managers on service plan documentation including identifying a plan for those youth who exhibit high risk behaviors to minimize the risks to child and others.  Service plans are being reviewed specifically for this content for all plans completed past this date and additional training is being provided on an as needed basis to address this area specifically. Regular review of this material will be provided to therapist and case managers to increase compliance

Deficiency Narrative: A staff member has been using belittling language in the presence of and/or direction of residents.

New Life will also provide training on reporting Serious Incidents and communication of such events to administration.  Training will be conducted on 11.2.20 with Administrative personnel and delivered to others during various meetings being held 11.2.20  11.6.20.
